comments.commentBody: None of what four?  The two Dallas nurses were infected by Mr. Duncan.  Dr. Spencer was infected in country.  the Maine nurse doesn't have Ebola.  Mr Duncan was infected by an Ebola victim in Liberia.

a very comfortable setting . . . in Liberia.

not funny.

Humanitarianism like all other important human values begins at home. Yes, the majority of U.S. citizens want to help stop the ravages and spreading of Ebola in western Africa, but not at the risk of importing Ebola here. We are NOT helping anyone in Africa with incurring another Ebola related infection or fatality.

The hypocritical, disingenuous and condescending attitudes expressed by the White House, CDC, WHO and several quoted medical professionals who failed for months to provide a credible and effective response to the Ebola outbreak in Africa. Provided insufficient and misleading information to the public on isolation procedures and incubation periods of Ebola. It is insulating to insinuate medical volunteers are more concerned about a quarantine upon return instead of direct exposure to Ebola with a 70% lethality and no proven vaccine. Why announce one policy for civilian volunteers and implement a contradictory policy for the military?

The range of Ebola incubation is 2 - 25 days meaning someone can contract Ebola and be infectious within 48 hours. Taking a body temperature reading without knowing when the person was last exposed to Ebola is useless. Also 12%-15% of Ebola infected people DO NOT get fevers but are infectious. Ebola is the same class of viruses as Influenza there is no biological limitations preventing it spread like the flu. Environmental factors like higher local ambient temperatures may explain Ebola not spreading like the flu....yet.

Elizabeth,

Please stop repeating the "we know that Ebola cannot be transmitted by casual contact" myth. We do not know that. See numerous other comments to this article.

We do not have the slightest idea how several of the people in this country ( and several in Europe ) were infected. We know where, and roughly when, but not how. We have zero idea how it is spreading in Africa at the moment. We can't even count the dead. If it mutates -- or already has -- we'll have even less idea.

There are certainly non-human reservoirs (from whence it springs in Africa every decade or so). We don't know which species, or how many. We don't know if North American animals can carry it.

We know very little about this disease, in fact. It would be nice if the facts were otherwise, but many things that would be nice are not so.

SMS said " I called the one hospital near my child and was told they couldn't tell me if they were in network with Humana, they didn't know. Of course, being in-network depended upon our particular plan."

When you go to a provider, guess how the provider knows that you are in network for that provider. They call the provider line at Humana and enter your Humana ID from your card or they do it electronically. That is the only way they do it. That is why they usually ask for your information before you actually go to that provider, so they can get those assurances.

Also, I have written a lot of business with Humana because they happened to be the best price to benefit plans on the Marketplace Exchange in Florida during the last open enrollment and I have used the online provider search with most prospects and it worked fine.

Now their network isn't everywhere, but it is state law in every state that I am aware of that if there is life or limb type of emergency all insurance companies must cover any provider as "in network".

If it is not a serious emergency and if you are in an area where the plan is not marketed or providers are not available, you must pay for it yourself and if you don't have a PPO with out of network coverage, you are not covered. But that is the same as insurance has been for the over 15 years that I have been an independent agent.
To which we should add another Menckenism: "Democracy is the theory that the common people know what they want, and deserve to get it good and hard."

Diana, not lumping ourselves under party banners sounds attractive on the surface but it would not solve a thing. The parties themselves are Potemkin villages, projecting an illusion of the power they have actually surrendered to their financiers. Of course there has always been money in politics, but the real rot and corruption set in with recent Supreme Court rulings. No longer does money just seek out a party of its preference that's based on genuine popular support; big money now has the power to shape parties in the image it wants.

This has skewed our entire political spectrum. Nuance has no place in party politics and, while popular opinion is probably as nuanced as ever, this too may end up being undermined by the bad example set by the pols. The right has only the far-right to go to, and the left has to be content with a center that permits no straying in a progressive direction. That’s what defines the range of opinions in our media and that’s what empowers the partyism that Brooks decries. The public rarely gets to hear of nuance if it’s off the media’s radar. The Progressive Caucus is the most numerous in Congress, yet its budget proposals never saw the light of day among the news readers and talking heads.

The answer is not to weaken parties even further, but to strengthen them so they can once again represent diversity of views within them and between them. Let’s start with real political finance reform.

Swift is the cotton candy of the brainless signifying nothing. That anyone gives her credibility as a performer smokes too much blue. She is simply awful and trite to boot. Shame on the Times for wasting precious space on her.

And there is a great deal of evidence that the fix was in for the Giants to win the 1905 series.
It's interesting that no one in the history of the World Series has ever matched Mathewson's 3 shutouts and it is doubtful anyone ever will.

just one last thing....

Mathewson pitched in 4 world series, won once; lost thrice. and since complete games matter so much in this matty score... he has 5 win 5 losses in 11 games (10 of which were CG).

Yeah he had a great year in 1905 ( 3 of his 5 wins in 11 starts) ...but that was about it as far as WS are concerned.
True enough, but this review is of a pop artist; however good she is cannot worthy of a half hour of pseudo-serious gushing as if she were a genius-sized Mozart.  Keep it in perspective.

I was just watching the episode out of any hope to view some spy game in action, when finally Saul stepped in. Yes, he was miserable in getting caught in the most basic trap by inducing thoughts, two spies go in and out of bathroom where his target was, in too short time to make any investigation, so the only hope is that the target is wounded/dead. So, why Saul should step in?? Ah, ok to be caught and gagged in the trunk of the Ayaan's uncle, directed to northern Taliban outpost.
Well, i was always saying "Hail to Quinn !!" after the quarrel with Carrie, ( i'm expecting her brightness to come back after her medicines will be substitued by ISI). He made good points: selfish doing, neglecting her squad, interrupting her line of command, and so on. But, for once, the writers indirectly answer the question i poised last week: "What's about Mark's legs"- Mark being the white autist of Farah. And the answer is coming directly from Quinn: "Go and place this tracker, Farah, i could do it myself if i wasn't white". And you wonder why Farah is enthusiastic of spying? What about the twin Pakistani bribers of the spy squad? Didn't they have driver's license? Again what's the point in not being covered in action: see Saul, see Farah, see Carrie, see Quinn, see ISI five elements squad for kidnapping Saul. O.K. i get it. We are supposed to expect for Carrie to turn the table through Ayaan. Finally, the Ambassador short selling her husband is incredible. At all, if first-talking with a spy
David, how about the quality of healthcare in Dallas or in Madrid? Is it so much better than Manhattan too? Doesn't seem to have helped much.

Interesting but silly argument you make, David. We thought the Dallas healthcare system was sophisticated too - but it proved otherwise. Time will tell if Manhattan healthcare workers are any better trained and have any better facilities. The healthcare workers returning from West Africa, however, are experts compared the people who have treated ebola patients so far in the US.

The facilities in West Africa may not be high tech - but its the experience that matters most in protecting oneself from exposure to this disease. Technology helps with decontamination.

michjas
The most sense here. Thank you. But bless those nurses on the subway.
They're the real heroes.

Let's try to think the new rules through.   Over the weekend, we had Ms. Hickox quarantined while dozens of health care providers treating Dr. Spencer were probably commuting by subway.  I want to thank the governors for their show of incompetence.  Can we get Colbert on this?
She was on TV today.
I guess you missed the NY Times round the clock hyping of that talentless moron Jay Z. This is par for the course.

Is the New York Times owned by Taylor Swift's record company? Why in the world would she even get this kind of press? A 30-minute podcast discussing the artistic merits of musical drivel? Are you kidding??? This is comical.

.
@pegkaz:

Archie Panjabi's contract status had already been discussed in previous weeks in these Comments (and maybe in the blog itself?). She is signed to CBS only through this season and has signed w/someone else to do a pilot.

People associated w/the show have made no secret of it; the Kings have discussed it openly. What would be a spoiler is if someone told us when or how she will be written off the show.

Anyway, Cary has been barred from being near her, and Alicia hasn't been in a room w/Kalinda for more than 30 episodes (someone is keeping count, but I don't remember who). Given that, you can't be too surprised that the character is going off.

I'm sorry you felt spoiled but in this case I considered it totally legit to print the Comment.

Millions of Americans get the flu and go to work, to the grocery store, to church, sneezing and hacking and coughing. They fly on airplanes sneezing and hacking and coughing.

30,000 Americans die from the flu they catch from OTHER PEOPLE.

And no one utters a peep.
I don't listen to her, but I recognize she is brilliant. It's utterly antithetical, but she's using the same archetype that Dylan used in the mid-60s.

My thoughts that I posted after the first episode, aired September 20th.

I'll be glued to the screen for this season. Brava and Bravo to the King's for their superb show.
22Recommend

What has happened to this show? Are the Kings involved in something new? Have they delegated TGW to some underlings? If so, for shame!

Why have the Kings allowed their intelligent and thoughtful show to become a travesty?

Kathy,

So right about Christie. But a federal policy of travel restriction and following and monitoring returning "aid workers" would have already been in place.
Took the keys out of my keyboard!

I was totally OK with Carrie ordering an airstrike on a wedding. But My God! She had sex with a young man! I don't see how I can ever get over that.

I was impressed with Saul's abduction, though. I bet right now he's wishing Showtime had never aired Dexter in Pakistan.

Today, thanks to the NY Times, is the first time I've ever heard Taylor Swift. I see her beautiful face everywhere I go.

Sadly, you are absolutely correct. This is plain awful. I find the cynical use of black people in the video, calculated to lend some air of hipness to the melange of cliches, offensive. You think of the vast contributions to music in America thanks to black artists and THESE are the idiots she chooses to emulate?
I have no idea what you're trying to say here. Is she exploiting white ballerinas? And who are the idiots again? You sound very conflicted - that's what I get.

It's jaw-droppingly bad. It's autotuned consumer tested lowest common denominator department store buying music.

The only way you could get more synthetic and manipulative than Taylor Swift is to sell songs sung by a perfect computer avatar singing head.

thanks for the warning.

are you the surgeon general of music?

i am now worried about what i am really listening to.

is this like the beatles white album played backwards?

i did that you know and all things worked out as far as i can tell.

EOS

Agree completely.

These other folks should take note.

Unless they are too busy divining the real and worthy music from all the rest.

EOS
Allow me to be the counterpoint here and say "hey Taylor, please kindly take your boring studio-generated noise pollution somewhere that'll appreciate it, like LA or Scandinavia."

Really not likely to check this music out, but bravo to her for choosing to continue to grow. Someone this young should not allow themselves to be boxed in. As a longtime fan of Todd Rundgren, who could also be fairly called a shape shifter, I'm fond of the surprise I got from each subsequent release.

(I am not equating Ms. Swift's output with Mr. Rundgren's, though I do wish her well, and I hope she enjoys a long stay in NYC.)

SMA,

Remember, the risk is "next to nothing" as you put it, only at the present time.

The longer we delay fully addressing this epidemic at its source the more suffering is imposed on West Aficans. Their suffering is not only economic, by the way. Ebola is destroying the social fabric of many communities.

But, if you really only care about Americans: Be mindful if we do not address Ebols at its source in Africa THE GREATER LIKELIHOOD THAT THIS DISEASE WILL BECOME ENDEMIC IN AFRICA with THE GREATER LIKELIHOOD IT WILL TAKE HOLD IN THE US. We live in a globalized society and much as you might want, we cannot escape the effects of globalization.

Please remember, too, that most of those people entering the US from West Africa are US citizens or legal residents. They have the same rights as you or I and as the health care providers who are caring for Ebola patients in the US. There is a certain incongruity in that some states are quarantining returning health workers but not those in the US. Would Gov. Christie have quarantined the health providers who took care of the nurse over the weekend had it turned out that her alleged symptoms were confirmed to be those of Ebola? I think not.

You need to educate yourself about epidemics and reassess your moral compass if you think that American lives are the only ones that should be protected from the ravages of this disease.

The best way to protect Americans is to stop Ebola in Africa. And that requires volunteer medical workers, who would be deterred by a quarantine when they have no symptoms. So a heavy-handed quarantine actually INCREASES risk to Americans.

We've been given the same rationale for invading Afghanistan and Iraq. Stop extremism in those countries BEFORE they train terrorists who will come here. Conservatives bought that argument--so why don't they buy it with Ebola?

Nightwood,

I don't believe SMA said anything like that. He/She merely said that the American government's job is not the preservation of West Africa. It is, astonishingly to some, the preservation of America. This is why, for example, when we have a war, we drop bombs on OTHER places, not here.

All countries work on generally the same principle.

So the troops who are working in West Africa are being quarantined at an American air base in Vicenza, Italy for 21 days before they come back to the states, but we can't do the same with medical workers or people who have contact with Ebola patients in West Africa. Each declaration from the President, the CDC etc seem to have as its primary goal the eradication of Ebola in West Africa with an attempt to preserve its economic viability. I'm sorry......this should not be the priority of the American government.....the protection of the American people should come first before any do good acts abroad. What is it that they don't understand? Americans do not want to sacrifice even one American to this disease. So while the medical workers sacrifices in West Africa can be admirable, they do not have the right to pose ANY risk to Americans. It is not good enough to say that the risk is next to nothing. They all need to be quarantined.
